title: Buy Indian Set-Aside (specific to Department of Health and Human Services, Indian Health Services): SOURCES SOUGHT IEE/ISBEE Crow Service Unit Hospital Laundry Services
buyer: Department of Health and Human Services
agency: Department of Health and Human Services
description: The Billings Area Indian Health Service is issuing this Special Notice RFQ(SN)-CSU-22-012-JJP Sources Sought Synopsis as a means of conducting market research to identify any potential vendors including IEE (Indian Economic Enterprise) or ISBEE (Indian Small Business Economic Enterprise) sources pursuant to the Buy Indian Act (25 USC 47). The Indian Health Service is attempting to locate qualified and eligible IEE and ISBEE sources ?Native American Owned and Operated Businesses? that can provide a Requirement for Hospital Laundry Services for the Crow/Northern Cheyenne IHS Hospital, Crow Agency, Montana, 59022.? The result of this market research will contribute to determining the method of procurement. The applicable North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code assigned to the procurements is: 812332 and the small business size standard is $41.5 million.? Laundering Services are required for The Crow/Northern Cheyenne Indian Health Service (Crow Service Unit) located in Crow Agency, Montana. The CSU processes an average of 1,500 pounds of soiled linen a month, with an approximate volume of 18,000 pounds of soiled linen a year. This amount fluctuates depending on patient admissions at the 24-bed health facility. Place of Performance: Crow Service Unit????????????????? 1 Hospital Way?????????????????????? ? Crow Agency, MT 59022?????? ?? THERE IS NO SOLICITATION AT THIS TIME. This is a request for capability information and does not constitute a request for proposals. Submission of any information in response to this market survey is purely voluntary. The Federal Government assumes no financial responsibility for any costs incurred. If your organization has the potential capacity to provide these contract supplies, please provide the following information: 1) Organization name, address, email address, Web site address, telephone number, and size and type of ownership for the organization, native owned certificate ?2) Tailored capability statements addressing the particulars of this effort, with appropriate documentation supporting claims of organizational and staff capability 3) Minimum order requirements 4) Minimum pickup requirements. ?If significant subcontracting or teaming is anticipated in order to deliver technical capability, organizations should address the administrative and management structure of such arrangements. All pickup and deliveries will be at Crow/Northern Cheyenne Indian Health Service, 1 Hospital Way, Crow Agency, Montana, 59022. This will be an All or None Award. BASED ON THE RESPONSES TO THIS SOURCES SOUGHT NOTICE/MARKET RESEARCH, THIS REQUIREMENT MAY BE SET-ASIDE, OR PROCURED THROUGH FULL AND OPEN COMPETITION. No feedback or evaluations will be provided to companies regarding their submissions. Submission Instructions: Interested parties who consider themselves qualified to provide listed supplies are invited to submit a response to this Sources Sought Notice by June 6, 2022 by 2:00pm /MST. All responses under this Sources Sought Notice must be e-mailed to johnna.pryor@ihs.gov. If you have any questions concerning this opportunity please contact: Johnna Pryor, Purchasing Agent at johnna.pryor@ihs.gov.

category_id: Services: Laundry, Linen, Mats, Washing Bids
title: S209--Miles City Laundry Services
description: Laundry and Linen Services Miles City VA Clinic Miles City, MT 59301 BRIEF SCOPE OF WORK (This is for information only) It is the intent of the Government for the Contractor to provide laundry and linen services for the Veterans Administration located at 210 S Winchester Ave, Miles City, MT 59301. The services shall consist of but are not limited to the following: Contractor shall furnish all labor, tools materials, equipment, transportation, supervision, linen (under the linen contract) and supplies to manage and perform all operations for the laundry and linen services. The contractor shall pick up the soiled laundry from a designated area at the Miles City facility 2-3 times per week with like delivery service for the return of clean laundry. Station laundry includes but is not limited to wash cloths, bath towels/blankets, and all bedding to include sheets and spreads/comforters. Residents' personal laundry includes but is not limited to pants, shirts and all undergarments. Some personal items may require ironing with separate pricing. A percentage of the laundry/linen from these facilities shall be classified as contaminated and shall be handled accordingly. All workmanship shall be in accordance with the best practices of the laundry/linen industry. SPECIFICATIONS-- LAUNDRY: Clean laundry shall be processed, packaged and protected from contamination in accordance with the policy of the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Hospitals. INVENTORY: The Contractor shall assume responsibility for any damaged or lost articles at their place of business and will guarantee the return of such articles to the Government in as good a condition as received. Any variation of quantities returned greater than 15% will require reimbursement from the Contractor to the Government. A fair value of the article lost or damaged will be determined by the Government and shall be reimbursed by the Contractor. This includes damage through improper use of chemicals, excessive heat or improper handling methods. The contractor shall provide the government with some type of system/checklist/tool for keeping track of the number and types of articles leaving the facility to be laundered so that the Government may track the number and types of articles returning to the facility. CONTRACTOR RESPONSIBILITIES: The Contractor shall obtain all necessary licenses and/or permits required to perform this work. The contractor shall follow all applicable state laws and regulations. Should circumstances arise that would significantly affect the scope of the contract or possibility inhibit the Contractor from performing the services described in this contract, the Contractor shall immediately submit in writing to the Contracting Officer a request for change in accordance with FAR 52.212-4. Upon receipt of such requests, the Contracting Officer will work with the Contractor to obtain a fair and reasonable solution. IMPORTANTR NOTE: This RFI (Request for Information) is for information only. No award will be made from this RFI. Please communicate via e-mail to Frances.Emler@va.gov by 15:00 on 04/17/2022 as to your company s ability to perform service per this brief Scope of Work. If interested, please provide the following: Please state your company s business size Please provide SAM Unique Entity ID number If you have a FSS/GSA contract that includes this service Provide FSS/GSA contract number if applicable

description:
The City of San Diego (City) is soliciting quotes for new reverse osmosis (RO) membrane elements to replace those existing at the Citys North City Pure Water Demonstration Facility (Demonstration Facility). The Demonstration Facility has two RO trains, each one producing approximately 0.5 million gallons per day of permeate. Train A is a two-stage design (12:5 array) with 119 membrane elements total, and Train B is a three-stage design (12:5:2 array) with 133 membrane elements total.

title: RFP for Patient Choice Referral List Software
description:
The San Francisco Department of Public Health (DPH) Zuckerberg General Hospital is currently seeking a software application that will generate a Choice List for patients of services that accept their insurance and meet their specific needs, and will meet Medi-Cal regulations by setting up an interface with Epic that allows for clinical documents and patient demographic information to be accessed and attached to referrals that can be electronically sent to qualified providers.

**Vendors proposed solution must be published as an available application in the Epic App Orchard at the time of bid response.**

For details, please review the attached RFP document and Zip files (A1, A2, A3) containing required forms and important supporting documentation.

For questions, please contact Ron Rossi at ron.rossi@sfdph.org.

category_id: IT: Medical Coding and Billing, Health Records, Hospital Software Bids
title: Health Data Utility Frame Work
buyer: Maryland Department of Health and Mental Hygiene
agency: Maryland Department of Health and Mental Hygiene
description: The Maryland Health Care Commission (MHCC) seeks a Contractor (also referred to as Offeror herein) to develop a Health Data Utility (HDU) Framework  A Guide to Implementation (Framework) that will assist Maryland, including government, health care organizations, software developers, and health information exchange (HIE) organizations to implement an HDU.  The purpose of the HDU Framework is to guide (1) the collection, aggregation, and analysis of clinical information, public health data, and health administrative and operations data to assist providers in care delivery and public health leaders in the evaluation of interventions and health equity; (2) the communication of data from public health officials and providers to advance disease control and health equity; and (3) the enhancement and acceleration of interoperability of health information throughout the State and across states.  The HDU Framework will serve as the basis for fully implementing the HDU in Maryland and a model for developing HDUs in other states.

description:
Direct Care Employer Registry Services

Solicitation ID: HHS0012071-1

Status: Posted

Contact Name: Katrinia Ender

Contact Number: 512-406-2428

Contact Email: katrinia.ender@hhs.texas.gov

Response Due Time: 10:30 AM

Response Due Date: 6/10/2022

Agency/Texas SmartBuy Member Number: 529

Solicitation Description:
The Texas Health and Human Services Commission (HHSC) is an agency within the Texas Health and Human Services (HHS) system. The Procurement and Contracting Services (PCS) division of HHSC administers solicitations for HHS.

HHSC PCS is seeking competitive bids to establish Contract(s) to join an existing web based direct care employer registry system (Enhanced System)**.  The Enhanced System would serve multiple purposes a direct care employer registry, a job matching portal specific to direct care positions, and a learning management and resource library.

Procurement Schedule - All Times are Central Time

Reference Section 2 for further information

description:
This Cahill project consists of construction of a new Balboa Park BART station passenger drop-off and plaza. The site area is approximately 48,500sf. This is a bid for the following trades only: Earthwork & Site Demolition, Misc. Metals, Sealants & Caulking, Painting, Asphalt Paving & Striping, Site Concrete, Landscape/Irrigation & Site Furnishings, Site Utilities/Lighting & Security Cameras. 

Requested Trades: 

BID DUE DATE: Thursday, June 23, 2022 @ 2:00 p.m 

Labor Requirements: Prevailing Wage (state or federal, higher of the two) for all trades / Union Labor required for carpenters, laborers, operating engineers only 
The developer has committed to meeting the San Francisco Contract Monitoring Divisions (SFCMD) non?discrimination, equal opportunity contracting and local workforce hiring participation goals including Small Business Enterprises participation, Construction Work Force Goals, Federal Prevailing Wage requirements. This project has a 20% SBE participation goal. 

All bid submissions and communication should be made on BuildingConnected. For any questions regarding this project or BuildingConnected access, please contact Cahill Estimating at estimating@cahill?sf.com.
.
.
.

category_id: Infrastructure: Painting, Striping, Marking, Glass Traffic Beads Bids
title: Airfield Paint Markings
description: LEGAL NOTCE INVITATION FOR BIDS Tweed-New Haven Airport Authority Tweed-New Haven Regional Airport Airfield Paint Markings Specifications and Bid Documents for the Airfield Painting at the Tweed-New Haven Regional Airport for the Tweed-New Haven Airport Authority, are expected to be available for examination at the offices of the Airport Manager, Tweed-New Haven Regional Airport, Administration Building 155 Burr Street, New Haven, Connecticut 06512 on Thursday, May 19, 2022. Interested parties may obtain copies of the bid proposal package by calling Tweed-New Haven Regional Airport at telephone no. (203) 466-8833, Ext. 1002 between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., or by visiting the Tweed-New Haven Regional Airport website at www.flytweed.com on Thursday May 19, 2022. Sealed bids will be received at the above address until 2:30 p.m. on Friday June 10, 2022. They will then be opened and read. Awards will not be made to any bidder whose name appears on a debarred list from performing contracts for the Federal Government, the State of Connecticut or any agency of the foregoing. The proposed contract is under and subject to Executive Order 11246 of September 24, 1965 and to the Equal Opportunity Clause. The Tweed-New Haven Airport Authority, in accordance with Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (78 Stat. 252, 42 U.S.C. 2000d to 2000d-4) and Title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, Department of Transportation, Office of the Secretary, Part 21, Non-discrimination in Federally-assisted programs of the Department of Transportation, hereby notifies all bidders or offerors that it will affirmatively ensure that any contract entered into pursuant to this advertisement, disadvantaged business enterprises will be afforded full and fair opportunity to submit bids in response to this invitation and will not be discriminated against on the grounds of race, color or national origin in consideration for an award. The requirements of 49 CFR Part 26, Participation by Disadvantaged Business Enterprises in Department of Transportation Financial Assistance Programs, apply to this contract. The Tweed-New Haven Airport Authority encourages participation by all firms qualifying under this solicitation regardless of business size or ownership. All contracts and subcontracts that result from this solicitation incorporate by reference the provisions of 29 CFR part 201, the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), with the same force and effect as if given in full text. The FLSA sets minimum wage, overtime pay, recordkeeping, and child labor standards for full and part-time workers.

description: The Technical College System of Georgia is accepting sealed bids on behalf of West Georgia Technical College (Owner) for Sealing and Striping Campus Parking Lots in strict conformity with the project plans, bidding documents and contract documents associated with this project. Wet Georgia Technical College is located at 176 Murphy Campus Blvd, Waco, Georgia 30182. This project has been posted as a sealed, electronic bid event within the Team Georgia Marketplace system. The project plans are attached to the bid event. Review the document titled Invitation to Bid located on the Georgia Procurement Registry bid notice and the Team Georgia Marketplace bid event for more information about the Mandatory Pre-bid Conference. MANDATORY PREBID CONFERENCE: West Georgia Technical College will be hosting a Mandatory Pre-bid Conference at 10:00 a.m. EST on June 15th, 2022 to discuss the scope of work associated with this project. Review the Mandatory Pre-bid Conference document attached to the GPR Bid Notice for more details. For technical assistance with registration or accessing your existing profile, contact the DOAS Customer Service Help Desk by phone at 404-657-6000 or by email at ProcurementHelp@doas.ga.gov, Monday through Friday, from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM, excluding State Holidays or any other day state offices are closed such as furlough days or closings in response to inclement weather.

category_id: Infrastructure: Painting, Striping, Marking, Glass Traffic Beads Bids
title: Traffic Pavement Marking Services
description: Electronic bids will be received by the City of East Point Purchasing Department, until Thursday, June 23, 2022, at 3:30 pm. The bids will be publicly opened and read aloud. Late bids will not be accepted. The times and locations of the services will be on an as needed project basis for the life of the contract. The City or its representative shall notify the Contractor, orally or in writing as to the time, location and type of services required for each assignment. Since this is an annual contract and the need for services are not known at the time of execution, the City does not guarantee any minimum or maximum amounts. All work to be performed shall be completed Monday through Friday during normal working hours unless the City is notified by the Contractor and receives approval at least 24 hours prior to a change in the work hours. Overtime is not expected. There will not be a mandatory pre-bid conference for this project. The Contractor shall perform and carry out Pavement Marking Services for items outlined in the Bid Price Schedule, and as specified herein in accordance with the Georgia Department of Transportation Standard Specifications, 2013 Edition, sections 652 thru 659. The location for this Work / Project is: [East Point, Georgia 30344] The Selected Provider shall furnish all materials, equipment, tools, supplies, and labor necessary to complete the required services as described herein and to the specifications as directed including all incidentals as determined by the East Point Public Works Director or his representative. All bidders questions shall be directed to the City of East Point, via email to tdjones@eastpointcity.org no later than 12:00 PM, Friday, June 10, 2022. The formal solicitation package may be obtained by visiting the Citys web site located at City of East Point Procurement (ionwave.net) . Solicitation documents cannot be obtained in person from the City nor by mail, email, fax, or courier service.

category_id: Infrastructure: Painting, Striping, Marking, Glass Traffic Beads Bids
title: Muralist
description: The City of Canton/Canton Cultural Arts Commission is seeking an artist or artist team to submit renderings for a new public art mural project to be installed on a wall along the back of Village Laundry, 401 Marietta Road, overlooking Harmon Park in Cantons historic Sunnyside neighborhood. Proposals are encouraged from artists and/or artist teams who have experience in creating large scale work on exterior walls. Award will be determined after submission  and additional information may be requested. Submissions may be emailed, mailed or hand delivered to Canton City Hall at 110 Academy Street, Canton Georgia. Please visit https://www.cantonga.gov/government/departments/finance/rfps-bids for complete details.

title: Striping
description: GEORGIA PROCUREMENT REGISTRY INVITATION FOR BIDS ADVERTISEMENT OGLETHORPE COUNTY, GEORGIA FISCAL YEAR 2022 GDOT LMIG, TSPLOST, & STRIPING PROJECT Sealed proposals will be received by the Board of Commissioners of Oglethorpe County, P. O. Box 261, 105 Union Point Road, Lexington, Georgia 30648, until 1:00 PM on Wed. June 16, 2022. All bids will be publicly opened and read aloud. Project Description: Project will consist of Traffic control, deep patching, OGI Leveling, Resurfacing, Milling Bridge Ends, Grading Complete, Full Depth Reclamation, G.A.B., Installing raised thermoplastic rumble strips, Shoulder building, grassing, and Re-striping on various County Roads. Mrs. Amy Forrester, Oglethorpe County Clerk will be Oglethorpe Countys contact person for acquiring bid packages. Mrs. Forresters phone number at the Oglethorpe County Commissioners Office is (706)743-5270. Blank bid forms may be picked up at the Oglethorpe County Commissioners Office at 105 Union Point Road, Lexington, Georgia. Contract Time: All work is to be accomplished within 6 months of the Project Notice-To-Proceed-Date to be issued by Oglethorpe County. Payment: Contractor to submit monthly pay request to Oglethorpe County and Oglethorpe County agrees to review and process pay requests within 30 days from receipt. A total of ten percent (10%) of progress payments, if applicable, will be retained until final acceptance by Oglethorpe County has occurred. Successful bidder will strictly adhere to all Current Georgia DOT Regulations, Current Standards and Specifications, all Current Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices guidelines, and all requirements included in the Project Agreement between Oglethorpe County and the successful bidder. Oglethorpe County reserves the right to reject any or all bid package documents received. All questions should be Emailed to Barry L. Wood, WOOD ENVIRONMENT & INFRASTRUCTURE SERVICES, INC. @ barry.wood2@woodplc.com

category_id: Infrastructure: Painting, Striping, Marking, Glass Traffic Beads Bids
title: Master Arts & Cultural Plan
description: The City of Norcross is soliciting highly qualified consulting firms or individual consultants to provide professional services for the Norcross Master Arts and Cultural Plan. The consulting firm/consultant is expected to perform responsible, professional work in the research, compilation of data, analysis and studies as described in the Request for Proposals (RFP), for the preparation of a Norcross Master Arts and Cultural Plan. The City is insistent that these documents be user-friendly with adequate visual aids and written in language that is easily understood. The purpose of the Master Arts & Cultural Plan is to develop guidance for the Norcross Public Arts Commission, to identify resources for the support of public art, and cultural programming throughout the City of Norcross, and to set priorities for implementation within Norcross. The proposal shall identify a unified community vision, establish a plan for potential selections and placement of public and cultural art throughout the community, and strive to educate the public about the valuable role public art plays in the community. The proposal shall contain practical policies and be reflective of information that will guide the Norcross Public Arts Commission and City of Norcross in a coordinated and consistent manner to create a more livable and vibrant community.

description:
Request for Qualifications # 22109

For Trade Contractors at Risk for the Renovations to the Gloucester Police Station and District Court.

The City of Gloucester seeks proposals from qualified Trade contractors interested in being prequalified for the Renovations to the Gloucester Police Station and District Court. Trade Contractor Statement of Qualifications Forms from interested trade subcontractors are sought for the following categories of work: Masonry, Resilient Flooring, Miscellaneous Metals, Acoustic Ceilings, Waterproofing Damproofing & Caulking, Painting, Metal Windows, Fire Sprinklers, Glass and Glazing, Plumbing Ceramic Tile, Heating, Ventilation & Air Conditioning, Electrical. The RFQ package will be available on April 13, 2022 by emailing purchasing@gloucester-ma.gov or at the Office of the Purchasing Agent.  Proposals must be received and will be opened at Construction Monitoring Services, Inc. 270 Main Street, Marlborough, MA  01752 no later than 11:00 a.m. on May 5, 2022. This Request for Qualifications (RFQ) is the first phase of a two-phase procurement process as set forth in MGL Chapter 149A. Only prequalified firms with DCAMM certification will be permitted to submit bids for the above categories.  The City reserves the right to reject any and all proposals or to accept that which is deemed in the best interest of the City of Gloucester, MA.  The City shall not be responsible for proposals arriving late for any reason.

category_id: Consulting: Appraisals, Assessments, Valuation Bids
title: Richardson Highway MP 351 Interchange Appraisals
description:
RFP #25-22-1-038, HSIP: Richardson Highway MP 351 Interchange Appraisals
The Northern Region State of Alaska Department of Transportation and Public Facilities (DEPARTMENT), Division of Preconstruction Services, Right of Way Section is soliciting for professional appraisal services for the HSIP: Richardson Highway MP 351 Interchange project.

A complete description of services is contained in the RFP Package.  Estimated period for performance of the Agreement is approximately June 2022 through December 2023.  Cost of these professional services is expected to be in the range of $10,000 and $20,000.

The Request for Proposals (RFP) Package will be available MAY 24, 2022, and may be downloaded from our web site at:  http://www.dot.state.ak.us/procurement/prosvcs/index.shtml; Under Request for Proposals heading, click on Request for Proposals less than or equal to $200,000  OR https://dot.alaska.gov/rfpmgr/sm.cfm Or the RFP may be obtained in person from the DOT&PF plans room at the Engineering Services Building, Room 3, 2301 Peger Road, Fairbanks, Alaska.  Persons residing outside the City of Fairbanks may obtain an RFP Package through the mail by telephoning (907) 451-2247 or TDD number 711 or 1-800-770-8973. (for Hearing Impaired, requires special equipment).  There is no charge for the RFP package.

FOLLOW INSTRUCTIONS IN THE RFP FOR SUBMITTING PROPOSALS: Proposals must conform to the RFP and be submitted with specified forms.  Submittals must be received at the address indicated on the RFP no later than JUNE 6, 2022, 4:00 p.m., prevailing time.

Currently proposals may be dropped off at our office.  A locked Drop Box is located at the outside entry of the Tech Services Building #3 (Contracts Building Main Parking Lot West Side Entrance).  Call or Text (907) 799-5632 when you place documents in the Drop Box and we will retrieve and timestamp your documents.  Thank you for your understanding and cooperation as we implement social distancing.

Individuals with disabilities, including the hearing impaired, who may need auxiliary aids, services, and/or special modifications to submit a proposal should contact the TTY number 711 or 1-800-770-8973, no later than one week prior to the submittal date to make any necessary arrangements.

category_id: Consulting: Appraisals, Assessments, Valuation Bids
title: RFP for Appraisal Services
buyer: San Bernardino County Housing Authority, California
agency: San Bernardino County Housing Authority, California
description:
The Housing Authority of the County of San Bernardino (HACSB) is seeking proposals from qualified professional firms or individuals to assist HACSB in Appraisal Services for properties within San Bernardino County, on an on-call basis that may include, but not be limited to, work in the following areas: Residential Appraisal Services (Single Family); and Multi-Family, Commercial and Industrial Appraisal Services.

The purpose of this Request for Proposals (RFP) is to select the most qualified firms for placement on a Roster that will be used to select firms for future assignments. Each firm selected for the Roster will sign an On-Call Contract for Appraisal Services that will not include any specific scope of work. Selected firms shall be able to provide the services described in this RFP within a time frame required by HACSB.

As work assignments arise, HACSB will select a firm from the Roster based upon HACSBs determination of which firm most closely meets the requirements of the particular assignment taking into account such factors as firm specialization, personnel and availability. HACSB will then notify the firm and negotiate the scope of work and compensation, to be formalized in a Work Order to the On-Call Contract.

The term of the Roster to be created by this RFP shall be five (5) years. In submitting a proposal to be considered for the Roster Program, the firm understands that there is no guarantee of any work or dollar amount under any On-Call Contract resulting from this RFP.

HACSB is soliciting proposals for two (2) categories of real property Appraisal Services. Firms may propose for either or both Categories listed below.

Category 1  Residential Appraisal Services (Single Family)
Category 2  Multi-Family, Commercial and Industrial Appraisal Services

Firms desiring to be considered for placement on the Roster must indicate in their proposal whether they wish to be considered for one or both Categories. The selected firms shall have qualifications and experience to perform the tasks related to the Category of Appraisal Services for which they are applying.

Angie Lardapide 909-332-6340
alardapide@hacsb.com

category_id: Consulting: Appraisals, Assessments, Valuation Bids
title: Broadband Assessment Services
description:
RFP #22-12 Broadband Assessment Services: Closes June 3, 2022

Notice is hereby given that the City of Escondido, a California municipal corporation (City), is
accepting proposals from qualified consulting firms to provide services necessary to develop
digital inclusion and broadband strategies.
Prospective consultants must submit one electronic version of their proposal via emailed to
smcelwee@escondido.org no later than 5 p.m. on June 21, 2022 (Submission Deadline). Any
proposals received after the Submission Deadline will not be accepted. Proposal files must be
clearly labeled RFP No. 22-12  Broadband Assessment Services.
There will be no public opening of the proposals. Proposals will be treated as confidential until
the contract resulting from the RFP is awarded or recommended for award.
Questions or comments concerning this RFP must be submitted via e-mail to Scarlett McElwee,
Administrative Coordinator for Information Systems, at smcelwee@escondido.org, no later than
5 p.m. on May 23, 2022 (Questions Deadline). Any questions or comments regarding this RFP
received after the Questions Deadline will be disregarded. Emails concerning this RFP should
state the following in the subject line: RFP No. 22-12  Broadband Assessment Services. Any
communication regarding or relating to this RFP with any City employee or official other than the
Administrative Coordinator of Information Systems is strictly prohibited. A summary of questions
from prospective Consultants and City responses will be posted on the Citys website at
https://www.escondido.org/purchasing by 5 p.m. on May 27, 2022.
Each proposal submitted in response to this RFP shall be in accordance with specifications,
instructions, and information contained herein. The City reserves the right to reject any or all
proposals for any reason it deems necessary, to waive defects or irregularities in any proposal,
and to accept the proposal deemed the most advantageous to the City. This RFP does not
commit the City to award a contract or to pay any costs incurred in the preparation of a response
to this request.

category_id: Consulting: Appraisals, Assessments, Valuation Bids
title: RFP for Parties of Interest Report (Lien Search)
description:
The County of Sacramento is seeking a contractor to provide Parties of Interest (Lien Search) Reports.  This is a countywide contract, but the main users are Community Development Department (Code Enforcement) and the Department of Finance, Tax Collection and Licensing Division. The required reports would be equivalent to a Litigation Guarantees Report or Trustee Sale Guarantees Report.  However, the County of Sacramento does not require title insurance and is not requesting a formal Ligation Guarantee or Trustee Sale Guarantee.  

The contract resulting from this RFP shall be for an initial two -year period commencing with execution of the contract by the Contract and Purchasing Services.  For reasons of economy and efficiency, the County reserves the right to extend a contract three additional one-year periods, for a total of five years, upon mutual agreement between the County of Sacramento and the contractor.

The Department of Finance, Tax Collector and Licensing requires Party of Interest Reports on a batch of properties prior to their annual tax sales.  Number of reports varies significantly depending on the actual defaults for the annual sale.  The quantity has ranged in from as low as 60 properties up to 400 properties.  The Tax Collector submits these properties in one major batch each year, with the potential of one or more smaller requests at different times of the year.

Code Enforcement requires weekly Party of Interest Reports on properties.  Most requests are single properties, but sometimes include 2 or 3 properties.  Code Enforcement conducts an annual lien hearing, which could include 65 properties.  

These volumes listed above are estimates only for planning purposes.  The County may require more or less reports during any contract year and does not guarantee to request a minimum number of reports for any resulting contract.

TOM REDDIE
SENIOR CONTRACT SERVICES OFFICER
9660 ECOLOGY LANE
California, CA 95827
Email: reddiet@saccounty.gov
Phone: (916) 876-6369

category_id: Infrastructure: Project Management, Planning and Scheduling Bids
title: Bids for GC Services - 1515 South Van Ness
description:
Project Summary: The City and County of San Francisco (the City), acting through MOHCD and the Sponsors of the parcel at 1515 South Van Ness Avenue (the Site) intends to construct an affordable rental housing project including units servicing low-income families, formerly homeless households, low-income people living with HIV, and ground floor commercial use servicing the surrounding neighborhood and the residents at the Site. In November 2020, the City released a Multi-Site Request for Qualifications for Sponsors to work with the City to develop new affordable rental housing projects on nine separate sites, located in various neighborhoods in the City, including this site. Chinatown CDC and Mission Economic Development Agency have been selected by MOHCD as the joint Sponsors for 1515 South Van Ness Avenue.

Scope of Work: General Contractor Services

LBE/SBE Requirement: The project is administered by the San Francisco Mayors Office of Housing and Community Development. The San Francisco Contract Monitoring Division (CMD) has assigned a 25% SBE participation goal.  The Sponsors are responsible for meeting the overall SBE participation goal, which includes any design and pre-construction services. The selected consultant will be responsible for assisting the Sponsors by providing forms regarding SBE professional services goals as it pertains to their scope of work. 

Bid Discount or Rating Bonus: A 10% ratings bonus shall be applied to: 
1)	SBEs proposed as the prime contractor/consultant; or
2)	Joint Ventures as explained here: (1) five percent (5%) to a Joint Venture with SBE prime contractor participation that equals or exceeds thirty-five percent (35%) but is under forty percent (40%); (2) seven and one-half percent (7.5%) to a Joint Venture with SBE prime contractor participation that equals or exceeds forty percent (40%); (3) ten percent (10%) to a SBE prime consultant or a Joint Venture among SBE prime consultants. The Ratings Bonus shall apply to each stage of the selection process, including proposals and interviews. Joint Venture Bid/ratings bonus will be added to the score only to a Joint Venture (1) that meets the requirements contained in the SF SBE Program and (2) when the SBE is an active partner in the Joint Venture, performs work, manages the job, takes financial risks in proportion to the required level of participation stated in the bid documents, is responsible for a clearly defined portion of the work to be performed, and shares proportionately in the Ownership, Control, management responsibilities, risks, and profits of the Joint Venture. The portion of the SBE Joint Venture's work shall be set forth in detail separately from the work to be performed by the non-SBE Joint Venture partner. The SBE Joint Venture's portion of the Contract must be assigned a commercially reasonable dollar value; or 

Note: A prime contractor/consultant that is not certified as an SBE that proposes to subcontract to a firm that is certified as an SBE but not as a joint venture will not be awarded a ratings bonus.

Instruction on How to Bid: Please submit one PDF digital copy of proposal by 4:00PM PST on June 15, 2022 to vlira@medasf.org, ldaza@medasf.org, Omar.rahmaoui@chinatowncdc.org, and Angelina.Perez@chinatowncdc.org. 

No late submittals will be considered. Note: The maximum MB for emails must remain under 20MB or your submittal may not be received. Please use a link to a secure file sharing system for larger files.
.
.
.
Event ID: SFGOV-0000007053

category_id: Infrastructure: Project Management, Planning and Scheduling Bids
title: RFP for 772 Pacific GC PreCon/Full Services
description:
(1)Project Summary: Following the footsteps of the International Hotel, 772 Pacific will be Chinatowns first new affordable housing in 20 years. CCDC understands that this project can serve the community with a meaningful commercial program on the ground floor and provide much-needed affordable housing for underserved seniors of all races reflective of the diversity of the City. The major challenge of the project is to achieve a financially feasible residential program on the sites small footprint. Additionally, it will be important to bring a creative approach to finding a balance between designing a thriving commercial program and re-introducing the cultural heritage of the banquet hall. New Asia is one of the last remaining banquet halls, and it was a popular social, civic, and political gathering hub for over three decades. The design team has the exciting challenge of bringing about a transformative difference to a culturally rich and historic neighborhood.

The developers vision for 772 Pacific is to create a mixed-use senior residential community of more than 86 deeply affordable studio and one-bedroom units, subject to SF Plannings feasibility determination and the project budget that MOHCD approves. We seek to create a high-quality living environment for senior households whose incomes will range between 30% MOHCD Unadjusted SF AMI up to 60% MOHCD Unadjusted SF AMI with more than half of the units for seniors with incomes at or below 30% MOHCD Unadjusted SF AMI. Our development will include on-site property management and resident services, front desk reception at the entry lobby, a community room for programing and events, and a neighborhood-friendly commercial component. As a rare new development, 772 Pacific will provide a tranquil refuge for seniors from Chinatowns busy streets below while providing an opportunity for seniors to age in place with dignity. Along with the housing, responding to stakeholder input regarding the ground floor commercial use will be an integral part of the work; it is important that the project maximize affordable housing while also continuing to host a community-sustaining ground floor use.

The successful General Contractor firm(s) will demonstrate its ability to participate in a series of meetings with the developer and the design team throughout the design phases to proactively provide input on innovative building components and constructability of design for cost effective, streamlined solutions.

(2)Scope of Work for RFP: 
The developer is estimating hard construction cost around $ 60MM, which is subject to change depending on the scale of the building. 
Selected General Contractor shall provide input on the following: 
	The team is interested in exploring emerging construction technologies that will allow the site to be developed in a cost-effective manner while balancing durability and facilitating maintenance. 
o	We will not rule out any system before understanding the cost, site, and staging implications. 
	Units are stacked for structural efficiency and seismic safety. 
	Recommendations for efficient residential unit layout and MOD-complying bathroom and kitchen configurations.
	Investigate and incorporate building dimensioning to:
o	Facilitate zero or reduced waste during construction,
o	Facilitate the inclusion of prefabricated walls and floor areas that can be efficiently craned and dropped-in-place during construction.
	Incorporate floor plans and exterior building envelope that can be efficiently built timewise and construction-wise. 
o	Establish an efficient ratio between window area and exterior wall area.
	Establish efficient floor-to-floor heights. Building will comply with the all-electric Code requirements.
	Plumbing is laid out for efficiency of plumbing runs
	Solar power and/or other natural resources to decrease hot water heating and other energy costs 
	Residential amenities to explore urban agricultural opportunities 
	In addition to achieving the minimum sustainability standards of TCAC and CDLAC, CCDC is interested in exploring Passive House design standards.
	Dos and Donts  Lessons learned from other affordable housing and/or MOHCD projects.

For purposes of this RFP, please indicate how long your team believes construction would last for this project. Please refer to the above schedule to inform your construction timeline. The Owner will normalize costs against construction duration among the applicant submissions, so please be mindful that this is an important part of your submission and the Owners calculation of your teams overall fee and general conditions.
772 Pacific	
Concept Development	July 2022  October 2022
Schematic Design	October 2022  February 2023
Design Development	February 2023  July 2023
Construction Documents	July 2023  December 2023
Financing Applications	2023 - 2024
Construction Start*	4th Quarter 2024  - 1st Quarter 2025
	*Construction start date subject to external funding NOFA dates & Building permit approval
DESIGN/PRE-CONSTRUCTION PROCESS

The Design and Pre-Construction Process involves plan review, cost estimating and value engineering by the Contractor.  The Contractor is expected to actively draw upon their experience, skills, and knowledge to add value to the project during this phase.  During the Design process, the Contractors duties will include the pre-construction services outlined in Attachment C: Memorandum of Understanding for Pre-Construction Services.

1.	Attend and participate in regular design meetings, in addition to other meetings as required by Owner;
2.	Conduct exploratory work as necessary or recommended to inform the scope;
3.	Assist the Project team in developing, managing and maintaining a realistic pre-construction schedule with established milestones as well as in developing the construction schedule;
4.	Provide complete project cost estimates, including unit prices, within four weeks following the completion of Concept Design, Schematic Design, Design Development, and at either 50% or 70% Construction Documents phase, and as may otherwise be required;
5.	Review plans and specifications as they are developed throughout the Design period and provide written comments;
6.	Participate in Cost Containment + Green Charette prior to and/or during Concept Design, and value engineering process by proposing design/construction alternatives and by researching the cost implications of design alternatives;
7.	Contribute to the green building design, construction, and compliance process;
8.	Research materials and methods pertaining to the Project;
9.	Secure multiple estimates from subcontractors for all elements of the proposed scope of construction.
10.	Organize and present all sub-contractor bidding information at each cost estimating/bidding stage of the project using a clear and well-organized method, in order to facilitate the development teams review and understanding of proposed contract pricing.  All bids are to be shared with developer, architect, and its construction representatives. Clear presentation and documentation of pricing and alternative scenarios is of critical importance to the development team. 
11.	Conduct scoping exercises and review plans for abatement and demolition work (if required) that will need to be conducted prior to the start of ground-up construction.


(3) LBE/SBE goals for the entire project and specific RFP
Small Business Enterprise Contracting: Subcontracting/Professional Services/Suppliers
The project is administered by the San Francisco Mayors Office of Housing and Community Development (MOHCD). The San Francisco Contract Monitoring Division has assigned a 20% SBE participation goal for Professional Services. 

The Developer and the City strongly desire a contracting team that represents the diversity of the City and, in particular, that of the neighborhood. As such, General Contracting firms certified as DBEs, SBEs, MBEs, WBEs and LBEs are strongly encouraged to reply to this request. Please submit a copy of your DBE, SBE, MBE, WBE or LBE certification.

The selected General Contractor will be required to meet the SBE subcontracting goal of 20% for construction services and comply with the Small Business Enterprise Program rules. Please refer to Attachment A: SBE Program.
Website links for finding Certified DBEs/SBEs/LBEs:
	For SBE - https://caleprocure.ca.gov/pages/PublicSearch/supplier-search.aspx
	For DBE - https://dot.ca.gov/programs/civil-rights/dbe-search 
	For LBE - https://sfgov.org/cmd/lbe-certification; 
o	https://sfgov.org/cmd/file/2032

The San Francisco Contract Monitoring Division (CMD) will confirm that a firm is certified as an SBE under the San Francisco SBE program

(4) Bid discount or rating bonus
Ratings Bonus - The following rating bonus will be in effect for the award of this project for any proposers who are certified as an SBE, or joint ventures where the joint venture partners are in the same discipline and have the specific levels of participation as identified below. The rating bonus applies at each phase of the selection process. The application of the rating bonus is as follows:
 A 10% ratings bonus shall be applied to SBEs proposed as the prime contractor/consultant; or
 Joint Ventures  A Rating or scoring Bonus will be added to the total proposal score and the total interview score (for firms selected for an interview) in the following breakdown: 
(1) five percent (5%) to a Joint Venture with SBE prime contractor participation that equals or exceeds thirty-five percent (35%) but is under forty percent (40%); 
(2) seven and one-half percent (7.5%) to a Joint Venture with SBE prime contractor participation that equals or exceeds forty percent (40%); 
(3) ten percent (10%) to a SBE prime consultant or a Joint Venture among SBE prime consultants. 
The Ratings Bonus shall apply to each stage of the selection process, including proposals and interviews. Joint Venture Bid/ratings bonus will be added to the score only to a Joint Venture (1) that meets the requirements contained in the SF SBE Program and (2) when the SBE is an active partner in the Joint Venture, performs work, manages the job, takes financial risks in proportion to the required level of participation stated in the bid documents, is responsible for a clearly defined portion of the work to be performed, and shares proportionately in the Ownership, Control, management responsibilities, risks, and profits of the Joint Venture. The portion of the SBE Joint Venture's work shall be set forth in detail separately from the work to be performed by the non-SBE Joint Venture partner. The SBE Joint Venture's portion of the Contract must be assigned a commercially reasonable dollar value.
 A prime contractor/consultant that is not certified as an SBE that proposes to subcontract to a firm that is certified as an SBE but not as a joint venture will not be awarded a ratings bonus.

 SBE FORM No. 1 - CONSULTANT/JOINT VENTURE AND SUBCONSULTANT PARTICIPATION REPORT: All proposers are required to complete this form and include the names of the SBEs being used, lower tier SBEs, as well as non-SBEs and a description of the work they will perform, the services or supplies which will be provided by each and the dollar value of each SBE transaction. This completed form must be submitted with the proposal.
 SBE FORM No. 2 - SBE CONSULTANT/JOINT VENTURE PARTNER/SUBCONSULTANT  GROSS REVENUE DECLARATION: An SBE consultant/joint venture partner and listed SBE subconsultants or suppliers, including lower tier subconsultants or suppliers, must complete this form AND submit listed firms current SBE certification. The prime shall collect the completed forms and submit them with its proposal on the proposal due date. The SBE consultant and listed SBE subconsultants or suppliers will need to submit this form declaring, under penalty of perjury, that their total average gross revenues for collect the completed forms and submit them with its proposal on the proposal due date. The SBE consultant and listed SBE subconsultants or suppliers will need to submit this form declaring, under penalty of perjury, that their total average gross revenues for the past three years are equal to or below the applicable income thresholds for the specific category of the contract. Refer to the revised SBE FORM 2.

For more information about the San Francisco SBE program as it relates to this solicitation, please see Attachment A and/or contact Selormey Dzikunu; selormey.dzikunu@sfdpw.org at the City and County of San Francisco Contract Monitoring Division.

(5) pre-bid meeting info
Deadline for submittal of questions on RFP is due at 4pm on May 17, 2022.


(6) instructions on how to bid
CONTRACTOR QUALIFICATIONS SUBMISSIONS

1.	AIA Document A305, Contractor's Qualification Statement
All applicants must complete the AIA A305 Contractor's Qualification Statement or similar formatted form.  The AIA A305 does not need to be notarized.

a)	In responding to Sections 3.4 and 3.5 of the AIA A305, major construction projects shall be understood to mean all rehabilitation projects over $5 million and new construction projects over $10 million. In responding to both Section 3.4 (Major Projects in Progress) and Section 3.5 (Major Projects Completed in the Past 3 Years) of the AIA A305, please use the attached form to provide this information (see Attachment G). Identify General Contractor staff involved in each project. Please provide contact information for owner and architect of each project. On a separate sheet or in the A305, please identify projects previously completed that required value engineering and cost estimating services. 

2.	Verification of Experience and Capacity
	In addition, please be aware of and conform to the following requirements, which are separate from those in the AIA A305.  Documentation must be provided for all requirements below:

a)	The contractor shall have been in business for a minimum of three (3) years without any official unresolved record of complaints registered or filed with the Contractor's State License Board of the California Department of Consumer Affairs. 

b)	During the past five years, the contractor shall have successfully completed, within time and budgetary constraints, a minimum of two (2) projects of construction type and cost similar to the proposed Project. If the proposed Project represents a Project larger than you have completed, please provide a statement demonstrating your capacity to complete the proposed Project successfully, including meeting bonding requirements.
c)	The contractor shall provide a summary of its current workforce and staffing, and a complete list of projects (including budget and duration) currently under construction, under contract, or in the negotiation stage.
d)	The contractor shall identify employees who will be responsible for providing services on the project, including pre-construction services. Please provide a staffing chart to include all staff who will work and charge to the project in both the pre-construction and construction phases of the project. This could include but is not limited to the Project Executive, Project Manager, Assistant Project Manager, Project Engineer, Pre-Construction Lead, Lead Estimator, and Project Superintendent. Provide resumes for these staff persons. Change to the following identified personnel listed in the RFP response will require Owners prior written approval: Lead Estimator, Project Executive, Project Manager, and Superintendent. Please indicate how the contractor will ensure continuity of its institutional knowledge of the project and decision making as the project shifts from pre-construction into bidding and construction, and which staff will continue from the pre-construction phase into the construction phase of the project.
e)	The contractor shall indicate its ability and capacity to perform value engineering and cost estimating services prior to construction while meeting all pre-construction schedule goals.  Please identify projects previously completed that required value engineering and cost estimating services and briefly describe the process and outcomes of specific value engineering efforts, including lessons learned from these projects.  Please identify the name(s) of your staff who will provide the actual cost estimating services for this Project and submit his or her resume.
f)	The contractor shall describe its process for leading the cost estimating and bidding process, and how information regarding sub-contractor bids and pricing is transparently communicated to development team in a comprehensive, well-organized method. An example of how the contractor has developed tools for sharing bidding and pricing information with clients is required. 
g)	The contractor shall describe their experience working with the Contractor Monitoring Division and CityBuild or other like/similar economic opportunity programs and provide goals achieved on recent projects for local hire and SBE/LBE/WBE /MBE as they were applied.
h)	The contractor shall describe their experience working with the San Francisco Mayors Office on Disability (MOD) or other like/similar inspectors.
i)	The contractor shall describe their knowledge of financing restrictions, particularly the California Tax Credit Allocation Committee (TCAC) requirements that are part of affordable housing project financing. The contractor shall affirmatively state they will work with the Owner to comply with all necessary provisions of TCAC in order for the project to secure financing. This includes proper estimating, scheduling, limiting General Conditions, and providing all necessary warranties. The contractor shall affirmatively state they will accept all provisions of the GMP contract regarding tax credit financing and will work with the Owner to remedy and repair any situation in the course of pre-construction or construction that would put the Owners tax credits at risk. The contractor shall affirmatively state they understand that contractor will have to provide documentation of costs after construction has been completed in order for the Owner to secure tax credit financing.
j)	In a separate narrative, detail specific experience with and knowledge of:
i.	New construction mid- to high-rise developments of comparable size and scope in San Francisco and surrounding Bay Area, and any processes, systems and/or materials that are particular to this type of residential construction. If no prior San Francisco experience, please describe Contractors experience and solutions to working on challenging urban infill projects, and how these projects may apply to this specific Project site.
ii.	Working with a client, such as CCDC, that has an array of stakeholders that have input on decisions, including construction related changes, VE, etc. For example, CCDC often has to inform and receive direction from other departments within the firm for programmatic changes that can lead to longer timeframes for decision-making.
iii.	Green building construction and complying with and/or exceeding Green Point Rated construction criteria or other like programs (LEED, Passive House, etc). Please provide a brief description of any experience with Passive House and assessment of applicability for 772 Pacific. 
iv.	Equitable hiring and promotion practices. Please detail how your firm is working to ensure that women and people of color are represented at all levels of your organization, as well as supporting the advancement of women and people of color in project management and construction.  

v.	Please provide a brief description of experience with emerging construction technologies and their assessment of potential applicability to 772 Pacific. 

vi.	Please describe experience with design-build and/or design-assist MEP and speak to the initial assessment of efficacy for 772 Pacific. 

3.	Proposed Fee and General Conditions 
All applicants must submit a fee, general conditions, and general requirements proposal. Applicants should use an estimated hard construction cost of $60 million and place duration information and general conditions into the template included in Attachment H (additional lines may be added). All estimated construction cost and duration are preliminary for fee proposal purposes only and subject to change. 

The submission must include:

	A proposed fee (based on a percentage) for the estimated construction contract amount of $60 million, which does not include overhead and profit. 
	Itemized general conditions costs based on the aforementioned contract amount. For the purposes of calculating the general condition costs, applicants should propose a construction duration in which they believe they can successfully complete construction of the Project, excluding demolition which will be placed under a separate contract.
	Itemized/proposed general requirements, with line item breakout, must be provided.
	Proposed fees for general conditions, overhead and profit must not exceed the TCAC, HCD, and City of San Francisco maximum allowable fees.
o	Please note: MOHCD has indicated they will not accept proposed GC held Contingencies over 5%.

4.	A sample from a recent, comparable project of each of the following:
	Cost estimate, including closing construction contract amount and construction cost at completion
	Plan review comments from a CD progress set of documents
	Construction schedule indicating critical path
	Bid summary or bid-tabulation information
	List of clarifications and exclusions 

5.	Acceptance of the terms of the Memorandum of Understanding & Proposed Construction Contract
The contractor shall affirmatively state their acceptance of all terms of the proposed Memorandum of Understanding and proposed Construction Contract (to be provided by 5/25/2022) or identify specific terms to which they take exception. This affirmative statement or list of contract terms must be included with the contractors proposal.

6.	Selection Process
The short-listed contractors will be evaluated on the basis on the fee proposal, submitted documents, interview by the selection panel and reference calls made in this phase.  

Following the interviews and reference calls, the highest-scoring/ranking applicant will be conditionally selected for the purposes of negotiating a Memorandum of Understanding (see Attachment C) for pre-construction services with expectation to contract for construction.  

TERMS AND CONDITIONS 
This section outlines the terms and conditions which will be set forth in the construction contract.  In submitting the contractor qualifications, the contractor acknowledges that he/she has read and understands that these terms and conditions apply to the Project.  Owner reserves the right to revise and/or add any terms and conditions beyond those set forth below. 

Insurance and Bonds
The Contractor will be required to post payment and performance bonds in an amount equal to 100% of the construction contract.  The bond issuer shall be listed in U.S. Treasury Department Circular No. 570.  The Contractor shall obtain and maintain Worker's Compensation Insurance to the extent required by law.  The Contractor shall maintain General Liability Insurance in accordance with the MOHCD requirements as found in Attachment I. Please note that while Attachment I references HUD, this is not a HUD project. The project will most likely have an Owner-Controlled Insurance Program (OCIP), please see Attachment J.
.
.
.

An Equal Opportunity Employer,


is requesting quotations from all qualified


WBE,MBE


sub-contractors and material suppliers for the following project:



2021 Greenback Lane Complete Streets Improvements Project



City/Location: Citrus Heights, CA


County: Sacramento



Owner: City of Citrus Heights



Bid Date: Tuesday 12/20/2022 at 3:00 PM



We are requesting bids for the following trades and/or supplies:


Teichert Construction is requesting quotes from all qualified subcontractors and suppliers including certified MBE/WBE firms for the following items of work, including but not limited to: all materials, labor and equipment for CONSTRUCTION AREA SIGNS, TRAFFIC CONTROL SYSTEM, RESET, ADJUST ROADWAY ITEMS, PLANE ASPHALT CONCRETE, CLEARING & GRUBBING, EROSION CONTROL, AGGREGATE BASE, ASPHALT CONCRETE, PAVING ASPHALT (ASPHALT CONCRETE), PAVEMENT REINFORCING FABRIC, RECYCLE, RECLAIM ASPHALT CONCRETE, MINOR CONCRETE STRUCTURE, ALTERNATIVE PIPE CULVERT, REINFORCED CONCRETE PIPE, PLASTIC PIPE, CONCRETE CURB & SIDEWALK- MISC, SURVEY OR HISTORICAL MONUMENT, THERMOPLASTIC TRAFFIC STRIPING & MARKING, LAND SURVEYING, CUTTING, SAFETY EQUIPMENT SUPPLIER, PETROLEUM, OIL, LUBRICANTS SUPPLIER (BULK ITEM), ASPHALT SUPPLIER(BULK ITEM), PIPE SUPPLIER, DRAINAGE SYSTEMS SUPPLIER, STORM WATER SYSTEMS SUPPLIER, PAVEMENT MARKERS SUPPLIER, ELECTRICAL & SIGNALS SUPPLIER, TRAFFIC STRIPES, MARKING AND TRAFFIC CONTROL MATERIALS SUPPLIER, MATERIAL TESTING SERVICES, LAND SURVEYOR, LEAD COMPLIANCE, SWPPP PLANNING, BOTTOM DUMP TRUCK, TRANSFER DUMP TRUCK, SUPER 10 DUMP TRUCK, WATER TRUCK, END DUMP TRUCK, STREET SWEEPING TRUCK and TRUCKER BROKER.



NAICS Classifications
Sector 23--Construction
All Other Specialty Trade Contractors
Other Heavy and Civil Engineering Construction



CSI Classifications
DIVISION 1 - GENERAL
TRUCKING-HEAVY HAULING
TRUCKS -- DUMP/TRAILERS
DIVISION 2 - SITE WORK
CONCRETE CURBS/GUTTERS
CONCRETE PIPE
PAVING/SURFACING
SIGNAGE
TRAFFIC SIGNALS



Bid documents can be viewed at or obtained from:


Docs & Plans Available from https://www.citrusheightsplanroom.com/



Request for qualified bids from Subcontractors, Suppliers & Truckers for the following project:
Project: 2021 Greenback Lane Complete Streets Improvements Project ? City of Citrus Heights 

Docs & Plans Available from https://www.citrusheightsplanroom.com/
Estimate: $2,400,000 Duration: 90 working days Agency Goals: 16.1% MBE and 6.9% WBE 
Teichert Construction intends to work cooperatively with all qualified firms seeking work on this project, including but not limited to breaking out contract work items into economically feasible units to increase overall MBE/WBE participation. Plans and specifications are available from the municipality listed above and the Teichert?s Roseville Estimating office. For assistance obtaining or regarding the plans and specifications, please contact the listed Estimator.

100% Payment and Performance Bonds for subcontractors are required. Teichert will pay bond premium up to 2%. Insurance Waiver of subrogation also required. However, certified MBE/WBE's are encouraged to contact Teichert and request assistance if they are unable to meet Teichert's standard bonding or insurance requirements. MBE/WBE's also are encouraged to contact Teichert for assistance in obtaining lines of credit, equipment, supplies, materials or related assistance or services. Subcontractor, Supplier and Trucker quotes must be valid, at minimum, for the award period stated in the contract documents. Please note that this is a prevailing wage project and Teichert Construction is Union signatory. Subcontractors will be subject to the terms and conditions of Teichert's subcontract and safety documents available at www.teichert.com/for-subcontractors.cfm. Submission of a bid to Teichert will confirm that you have reviewed and accepted Teichert's subcontract form. Conditions or exceptions in Subcontractor?s quote are expressly rejected unless accepted in writing prior to bid. Subcontractor scopes and supplier quotes are required 24 hours prior to bid. Additional information and or assistance to MBE/WBE's available from: *** All Subcontractor Quotes must have the Department of Industrial Relations # to be ACCEPTED ***




A. Teichert & Son, Inc. dba Teichert Construc


400 Sunrise Avenue, Suite 300


Roseville, CA 95661

title: Project-Based Voucher RFP
description: The Georgia Department of Community Affairs (DCA) is seeking request for proposals (RFP) from developers for the Project-Based Voucher (PBV) Program. PBV proposals are being accepted for up to 1,200 vouchers (the number of units to be funded) for new and existing housing construction projects within the 149 Georgia counties served by DCA. DCA must receive proposals no later than Monday, June 6, 2022, at 5 p.m. Participation in the PBV program requires compliance with Fair Housing and Equal Opportunity (FHEO) requirements. Please note that this is a paper solicitation, and it won't be submitted in Team Georgia Marketplace. To view additional information about the Project-Based Voucher program or the solicitation, click the link (https://www.dca.ga.gov/safe-affordable-housing/rental-housing-assistance/housing-choice-voucher-program-formerly-known-16) and you will be redirected to the GA DCA website.

category_id: Infrastructure: Project Management, Planning and Scheduling Bids
title: Greater Warren Conner Neighborhood Framework Plan Community Engagement
description: The City of Detroit is seeking professional services to assist P&DD with creating the Greater Warren / Conner Neighborhood Framework plan as described throughout this community engagement RFP with experience around: project management, meeting logistics and facilitation (in-person and virtual), tactical and pop-up engagement methods, survey and focus group design, and project communications utilizing multiple platforms. category_id: Infrastructure: Project Management, Planning and Scheduling Bids
title: RFQ for Construction Monitoring Services - Replacement of Electrical Cables and  Subway Structure Renovation
buyer: Delaware River Port Authority, New Jersey
agency: Delaware River Port Authority, New Jersey
description:
The DRPA hereby invites interested professional consulting engineering firms to submit a Statement of Qualification (SOQ) for Construction Monitoring Services in connection with Contract No. 10-K, PATCO Replacement of Electrical Cables and  Subway Structure Renovation.  This public advertisement constitutes the DRPAs formal solicitation to determine the interest of qualified firms in the Project.

The Scope of Services the Authority requires shall include construction monitoring services for the replacement and elimination of various power, signal, and communications cables running primarily within the Philadelphia tunnel of the PATCO system as well as traction-power equipment within Locust Street Substation, located in the area of the PATCO tunnel, below the concourse level and directly under Locust Street, immediately west of Broad Street, in Philadelphia.  The interested Construction Monitoring firm shall be note that the equipment replacements at Locust Street Substation represent a significant logistical challenge and that the firm will need to coordinate the work with PATCO and the Contractor to be completed successfully and without significant disruptions to PATCOs operations.  Multi-pair copper communications cable, the use of which has diminished significantly over the years at PATCO, will be eliminated, and any communications currently carried over copper cables will be moved to existing fiber optics.  The use of multi-conductor signal cable will be reduced by converting relay-based vital signaling to microprocessor-based vital signaling, placing signal communications between instrument locations onto existing fiber optics.  In addition to electrical portion of the project, the firm will also be involved with monitoring structural repairs to PATCOs Philadelphia tunnel.  Work will involve concrete repairs, type 1 and 2 spall repairs, crack injections, steel repairs, steel painting, and column repairs.  The electrical and structural portions of this project will be performed in PATCOs Philadelphia subway tunnel which runs 1.75 miles from 17th and Locust streets to the Front Street substation beneath the Benjamin Franklin Bridge.

Solicitation Description:
PURPOSE: The City of Leander, herein after City, seeks an agreement with a qualified Individual,
Firm, or Corporation, herein Respondent, to provide as-needed easement and right of way
acquisition services.

Typically, a City Project Manager will identify the need for such services in the course of engineering
design of City capital improvements projects for water, sanitary sewer, storm water, or roadway
improvements. The property rights needed may be either permanent or temporary. Acquisition
services may also involve services related to assisting the City with obtaining easements or rights of
way for existing utilities or streets where the Citys rights to maintain its facilities are not clearly
documented, or for other similar needed services.

Procedures for acquiring rights of way and easements must comply with the right of way acquisition
guidelines established under the Federal Uniform Relocation Assistance and Real Property
Acquisition Police Act and Senate Bill 18.

title: RFP for Employment Related Investigative Services
description:
The County of Sonoma is pleased to invite you to respond to a Request for Proposals for Employment Related Investigative Services.

The County seeks competitive proposals for employment-related investigative and consulting services, and will establish contracts with those proposers that the County determines are best qualified and most appropriate to serve the County on an as needed basis. The services required consist of performing internal investigations and related work that may cover a broad range of issues, including but not limited to equal employment opportunity (EEO), discipline, and liability. In an effort to facilitate County access to specialized investigative services for various types of employment investigations, master agreements with multiple contractors will be implemented. Workers compensation investigations are not included in the scope of this RFP.

For questions regarding this specific solicitation, email victoria.willard@sonoma-county.org.

Solicitation Description:
The Houston-Galveston Area Council, the fiscal agent for the Gulf Coast Workforce Board, is issuing this Solicitation on behalf of the Board and Workforce Solutions and is seeking a qualified contractor to perform professional services for the Workforce Solutions system. Any subsequent contract awarded under this solicitation will be executed with the Houston-Galveston Area Council as the contracting entity.

Workforce Solutions has a central Financial Aid Payment Office responsible for handling vendor billing and payments for our customers financial aid. The Financial Aid Payment Office works with our systems vendors by initiating vendor agreements and making billing and payment arrangements. This includes payments to childcare vendors, training providers, and support service vendors as well as payments to employers for on-the- job training reimbursements and custom training projects.

Respondents that propose to operate Financial Aid Payment Office may not propose to operate the Financial Aid Support Office.

title: RFP for Emergency Management Training
description:
The County of Stanislaus (County) is seeking proposals from qualified and experienced organizations for the provision of Emergency Management Training on behalf of the Countys Office of Emergency Services (OES), located at 3705 Oakdale Rd., Modesto CA 95357. 

The Stanislaus County Office of Emergency Services (OES), in compliance with the National Incident Management System (NIMS), Standardized Emergency Management System (SEMS), and Incident Command System (ICS), provides emergency management training to a diverse audience, including, but not limited to, emergency response personnel, government employees, disaster service workers and volunteers, non-government organizations, and private businesses. Training is provided at various levels to Boards of Supervisors, City Councils, elected officials, command and general staff, emergency managers, and emergency operations center management team members. Training may move staff toward meeting requirements of the National Qualification System (NQS) and the California Governors Office of Emergency Services (Cal OES) Emergency Operations Center (EOC) Position Credentialing Program.

category_id: Consulting: Emergency Preparedness, Disaster, Recovery, and Security Assessment Bids
title: RFP for Consultant Services to Develop a Security Strategy
description:
The City of San Diego, Office of Emergency Services Department (City), is seeking a Consultant to update the current security strategy. The selected contractor will develop a plan to update the 2017-2019 San Diego Urban Area (SDUA) Homeland Security Strategy, hereafter referred to as the Strategy. While the current Strategy may be used as a starting point and baseline guide for the update of this Strategy, this revised Strategy will more effectively and efficiently utilize the regions latest Threat and Hazard identification and Risk Assessment (THIRA) and Stakeholder Preparedness Report (SPR) as a central and consistent focus throughout the document. This focused method has not been included in previous updates to the Strategy.

The THIRA and SPR are the only two region-wide threat and hazard related products that are developed by City of San Diego Office of Emergency Services (OES) and required by Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for periodic completion and submission, to DHS. Their use and incorporation in the development of this update to the Strategy is now emphasized and intended to ensure greater consistency in addressing and implementing regional threat and hazard priorities. This conscious and active use of the THIRA/SPR to inform the Strategy will also ensure that the regional estimates, impacts, outcomes and evaluation based on the FEMA core capabilities that these documents describe and project are more consistently reflected in the Strategy, and as a result of collaboration and coordination among the regions homeland security stakeholders. The selected contractor will also continue to incorporate, as necessary, the risk analysis tools that have been used previously in the development of the Strategy (e.g., Cal COP products, liaison with appropriate LECC staff, and use of specialized OES maintained data bases that can all provide important inputs to the Strategy (e.g., SEAR and CIKR databases used and accessed by OES).

Beverly Asbill-Gumbs 619-236-5923
basbillgumbs@sandiego.gov

title: RFQ for Post-Hurricane/Disaster Recovery Operations Damage Assessment
description: Post-Hurricane/Disaster Recovery Operations Damage Assessment

category_id: Consulting: Emergency Preparedness, Disaster, Recovery, and Security Assessment Bids
title: Post Hurricane / Disaster Recovery Operations Damage Assessment
description:
Post Hurricane / Disaster Recovery Operations Damage Assessment

Solicitation ID: 1452A2

Status: Posted

Contact Name: Michael Forbes

Contact Number: 956-544-0871

Contact Email: mforbes@co.cameron.tx.us

Response Due Time: 11:00 AM

Response Due Date: 6/23/2022

Agency/Texas SmartBuy Member Number: C0311

Solicitation Description:
Cameron County requests qualifications from engineering, architectural and consulting firms (collectively, Consultants) interested in providing professional services to conduct post-hurricane/disaster damage assessment as part of the Countys overall Post-Hurricane Recovery Operations.  The County recognizes that immediately after a major disaster, local firms might not be able to respond quickly to a request for services.  As a result, the County is interested in contracting with firms both in the local area and outside the local area to ensure that an adequate resource base is available regardless of the extent of damage within the County.  This contract shall cover calendar years 2022 through 2027.



The concept for post-hurricane recovery operations is for the County to have a number of pre-event contracts in place that will provide personnel to assist local government staffs with damage assessment activities immediately after a hurricane or other disaster.  Damage Assessment Teams (DATs) will be comprised of government and Consultant personnel under the overall direction of Cameron County staff.  The work will entail preliminary assessment and documentation of the scope and nature of damage incurred throughout the County in accordance with direction and guidance provided by the County.  The work will also include detailed documentation of damage to public property and facilities.  The work may also include assistance with repair plans and specifications and/or assistance with monitoring contractors involved in emergency protective measures.  The County will provide necessary training on the assessment process and completion of the associated forms and records.



It is the County's intent to identify qualified Consultant firms, enter into an agreement with each qualified firm, and be able to activate as many firms as necessary to provide prompt damage assessment services immediately following a hurricane or other disasters. The unpredictable nature of hurricanes or other disasters precludes providing more detailed descriptions of the actual work assignments at this time.



The primary focus of the pre-positioned contracts is post-hurricane and other /disaster recovery operations.  Notwithstanding, the County may activate the same contracts for response to any disaster, natural or man-made, regardless of the scope of damage.  The County may contact any of the Consultants under contract at any time for assistance in this area.  The intent is that the firm will provide personnel to the extent of their capabilities at the time of the request.  Submitters should consider this concept.
